title: judge praises homeowner burglars ormskirk lancashire
story: David Oldham, 63, was congratulated after he bravely attacked burglar Craig Ford, 25, and his accomplice after finding them on his property in Ormskirk, Lancs.Ford’s blood was left on Mr Oldham’s clothing - helping later identy him - following the incident on April 5 at the £400,000 detached house.Derek Jones, prosecuting, told Liverpool crown court that at the time of the burglary Ford was already on licence from a three year sentence imposed in 2016.He told the court that Mr Oldham was home when he heard noises and looking out he saw Ford who had his coat zipped up with his hood down and looking upwards.He said: “Mr Oldham, a man of some substance, bravely went out to the side of the property and was confronted by the defendant who moved towards him.Fearing for his safety he punched him once to the face which knocked him to the floor and also knocked a tooth out.”The other intruder then jumped down from the roof landing in front of Mr Oldham who instinctively punched him to the face causing him to stumble backwards.Ford then told his pal “Shoot him, he’s knocked my teeth out” before telling Mr Oldham they would flee  he let them go.Four months later Ford was bitten by a police dog as he resisted arrest.Jailing the burglar on Friday for three years and four months, Judge Clement Goldstone, QC, the Recorder of Liverpool, said: “You’ve learnt two lessons I hope.One is you do not mess with David Oldham and, two, you don’t mess with the police.“I’m delighted to say that for your pains in committing these offences you now have one tooth less than you had before and you got bitten by a dog. It is the least you deserve.”Ford admitted burglary, assault and driving dangerously, while disqualied and without a licence, while his accomplice is believed to be at large.In an impact statement Mr Oldham told how he and his we had lived in their home for 19 years and the burglary had influenced their decision to move.He said he is not a violent person but had been forced to defend himself, and added that his we now feels insecure so they had had to make additional security measures to their home.Mr Oldham said: “It has changed my we and I and we realise how vulnerable we are.”Desmond Lennon, defending, said that Ford had been living an itinerant lestyle after his release from prison and “had gone off the rails.”At the time of the offences his grandmother, to whom he was close, was dying.

title: schools face headlice epidemic
story: A measure designed to save the NHS £100 million a year sees GPs being banned from prescribing “Bug Buster” kits - which cost the health service £4.92 each.The itchy bugs are likely to go round schools like wildfire, Community Hygiene Concern said, because poorer families won’t be able to pay the £13 needed for over-the-counter insecticides.A 2016 US study found 98% of headlice had developed resistance to non-prescribed remedies, while a study of 200 British children found almost 50% had caught lice in the past five years.Frances Fry, a spokeswoman for Community Hygiene Concern told the Observer: “Not everyone can afford to repeatedly buy head-lice treatments, which are very, very expensive and can be ineffective.”She added: “Children whose parents cannot afford the treatments will be victimised and bullied, and all the judgements and stigmas will .”An NHS England spokesman said: “This will free up to £100m to reinvest in better mental health, cancer and A&ampE services.“Clinical experts advise head lice can be safely and effectively treated by wet combing, with chemical treatment only recommended in exceptional circumstances.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: grenfell cladding ban new buildings
story: The rule, unveiled today, will apply to all residential buildings over 60ft.Schools, care homes, student housing and hospitals also come under the legislation being announced by Housing Secretary James Brokenshire.He will say: “It’s been over a year since the tragedy of the Grenfell Tower fire.This unimaginable horror has rightly shocked us all and underlined the need to do all that we can to see that such a disaster cannot happen again.“That is why I can confirm that I will change the building regulations to ban the use of combustible cladding for all high-rise residential buildings, hospitals, care homes and ­student accommodation.“And bring about a change in culture on building safety.” ­Combustible cladding is widely blamed for the Grenfell tragedy.The ban, revealed at the Conservative conference, will come into effect in late autumn. It will not apply to existing buildings.The Government already has a £400million programme to remove suspect cladding from all high-rise social housing in England.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: birmingham pub bombings ira james francis gavin
story: In a dramatic confrontation, the suspect denied any involvement in the  fatal blast as he was quizzed in a new ITV documentary.The man, who cannot be named on websites read in Northern Ireland, was approached by investigative reporter John Ware as he left a Tesco in Belfast.But he told The Hunt For The Birmingham Bombers: Ive got nothing to say... Well, you can ask what you want but Im not going to answer.Youre wasting your time.And his solicitor added: Our client denies all the allegations and does not intend to respond any further to the unfounded allegations you have made.A second man alleged by the documentary to have been involved is convicted IRA bomber James Francis Gavin, who has since died.Julie Hambleton whose sister Maxine, 18, was among the dead, travelled to Belfast in July to meet political leaders ahead of the new inquest.Seeing footage of the suspects denials, she broke down in tears, sobbing: “We could have walked past him when we were in Belfast.”Tonights documentary examines  what happened in the lead up to the night of November 21 1974, when two explosions ripped through two separate pubs, killing 21 and injuring 182 others.Victims were left trapped under the partially-collapsed roof with those passing by in the street were also injured by glass from shattered windows.The Provisional Irish Republican Army  has always denied responsibility but have widely been blamed.Six men wrongly convicted over the bombings in 1975 were freed in 1990.*The Hunt For the Birmingham Bombers is screened on ITV at 10.40pm tonight.*

title: llanfairfechan wales school ban kids playground conwy council
story: Furious parents with kids at Ysgol Pant y Rheydyn in Llanfairfechan, North Wales, have said their kids have become depressed as they cannot interact.Dozens made complaints to the school earlier this year about the uneven playground surfac.The school closed the grounds at the start of the summer holidays so repair work could take place but now officials have said it has been scheduled for October half term.One parent told The Daily Post: The issue over the playground was raised with the council in July. Why couldnt they have sorted this sooner?Another added: My daughter is unhappy in herself due to not being able to mix with her friends in the yard at play time. Why are children in Llanfairfechan being treated like second class citizens?Now school governors and council officials are arguing over who should foot the repair bill.Conwy Council initially said the school had reserved funding it can use, before later pledging to pay whatever is left over.But school governors say its the councils responsibility as the bill would leave them struggling to pay staff.Sun Online has contacted the council to explain how the work should be funded.A letter that was sent home to parents about the playground yesterday states: The surface has steadily deteriorated over the past four years and related accidents increased to such an extent that the board governors and the headmaster made a joint decision, over the summer break, to close it until it can be resurfaced.The decision was not taken lightly but our duty of care to both pupils and staff has been our primary concern.The area will be resurfaced during October half term and the yard will be re-opened on  to school on November 5.The cost of the resurfacing is going to be substantial and we are currently in protracted negotiations with Conwy Council regarding how we are going to fund this work.We will also need to fund raise ourselves in order to pay for some of the work that needs to be done.A Conwy Council spokeswoman told the newspaper: In common with other local authorities in Wales, Conwy Council is suffering severe cuts in funding, which means it can’t do all that it would wish to do.Some schools, however, maintain high levels of reserves - at the end of the 2017/18 financial year Ysgol Pant y Rhedyn had reserves in excess of £70,000.This meant the school had not spent 13 per cent of its allocation. This is money that could and should be spent on the education of pupils and their learning environment. She added: We understand the school has now made arrangements for the yard to be resurfaced during October half term. Conwy Education Services are contributing towards the cost.But Cathy Heavers, vice chair of governors at Ysgol Pant y Rheydyn told Sun Online there will be a huge impact on pupils and staff  they are forced to pay.She said: As Conwy County Borough Council has stated, there was indeed £73K in the reserves prior to July. But as of September 2018 our balance at is down to circa £45K, which is 7% of the budget reserves.Even at a standstill budget , the school is likely to have only £8K in reserve by the end of the year. Our financial position is probably better than many other schools in Conwy, due to the prudent financial management of the team at the school. Yet despite this, we’re still in a position where we’re unable to make ends meet. As things stand, this is unlikely to be enough to fund the current staffing structure - without even looking at the cost of resurfacing the school yard. Resurfacing the yard to make it safe for pupils will cost the school at least £14K, taking into account the contribution the Local Education Authority has agreed to make.It doesn’t take a mathematician to work out the impact this will have on pupils and staff. Parents have every right to be angry that the school are having to pay for this, when CCBC is responsible for maintaining the yard.

title: kate middleton mum carole selling zombie princess diana halloween costume
story: Zombie Sleeping Princess Costume is for girls as young as four and features an exposed rib cage and organs.But friends of Princess Diana have described the outfit as sick, linking the fancy dress costume to the princess who was killed in a car crash in 1997.Simone Simmons, a friend of Dianas, told The Daily Star: This is sicker than sick.This is really scraping the barrel.Its twisted and warped.Ms Simmons also hoped that people would boycott the website.The gory outfit is on sale for £10.99 on the website owned by the mother of the Duchess of Cambridge.Describing the costume, Party Pieces writes: Our Zombie Sleeping Princess costume in pink includes a dress with chest print detail.This not so pretty princess costume features a blood-drenched pink silky dress with a jagged skirt.The top includes a gruesome print of the poor zombie princesses rib cage and organs.This princess will be the scariest princess at any Halloween party.Majesty magazine Editor-in-Chief and royal writer Ingrid Seward is also said to have deemed the outfit to be in very poor taste.Earlier this year, Tesco also caused uproar by selling a fox hunter costume for children as young as seven.And Amazon went even further, stocking a Halloween costume of Anne Frank who was murdered in a concentration camp after years of hiding from the Nazis. Caroles daughter Kate Middleton, 36, became a princess herself when she married Prince William at Westminster Abbey in 2011.Other costumes on the Party Pieces site include a zombie cheerleader costume and an undead red riding hood.Party Pieces has been contacted for comment.

title: jacob rees mogg blasted for calling african country the peoples republic of jam jar
story: The top Brexiteer was accused of “casual racism” over the joke at a Tory conference fringe event.Mr Rees-Mogg made the quip during a pro-Brexit rally in Birmingham last night.He said: All the countries who are least interested in their people call themselves ‘peoples’, don’t they?“So the People’s Republic of China? Oh, that’s communist.“And the People’s Republic of Jam Jar, or something like that, of Libya, was what it was called when Colonel Gaddafi was in charge.”The dictator Gaddafi renamed his country the Great Socialist Peoples Libyan Arab Jamahiriya in the 1970s.It reverted to its original name after he was deposed and killed in 2011.Labour MP Alex Sobel, a backer of the Best for Britain campaign, hit out at Mr Rees-Mogg, telling the Mirror: “This not only shows the same sort of casual racism Boris Johnson has displayed but also a disdain for the rest of the world which would leave us isolated and economically eviscerated  he is allowed his hard Brexit.”And shadow minister Chi Onwurah joked: “Its their respect for other countries and attention to detail which will be such an asset for the Hard Brexiteers as they negotiate trade deals post-Brexit.”The Rees-Mogg rally attracted queues round the block as Tory activists lined up to pay homage to the leading Brexiteer.

title: samantha markle meghan sister sorry insults dad health
story: Samantha Markle, 53, was quizzed about her behaviour on social media after she slammed her sister on Twitter with bitter insults.Speaking on Jeremy Vine’s Channel 5 show this morning, she defended her decision to criticise her sister and said she wanted to get a message across from my father”.However, moments later she apologised to Meghan, 37, and said she would like to tell that there is “water under the bridge”.Samantha said: “I would just say that there’s so much water under the bridge and so much has spun out of control that was never intended to.“I think everybody was hurt at not being included or invited to the wedding.“I felt it could’ve all been nipped in the bud had everyone been included and we all agreed to move forward with positive resolve.“The hurt feelings wouldn’t have snowballed but, believe it or not, it doesn’t mean we don’t love you any less.“I just think that families can be this way when there’s confusion and when people are hurt.“So moving forward I apologise and I wish things could be dferent.”Describing her dad’s health, she said he is unwell and that his breathing is “challenged”.She also said she wants him to come to the UK and meet up with his daughter.Samantha said: “I would love for him to come here. I was hoping they would whisk him over on a private plane .“I think they were also concerned with his health but I think  things would have gone dferently it would’ve been better for his heath hand better for her.“I don’t think it was intentional, they didn’t understand what was going on and it had a horrible reciprocal effect. The hurt feelings continued.When asked about Prince Harry she described him as a true gentleman and added she is happy for the couple.She added: Harry is a such a gentleman and so savvy. I would say she has found her prince.“As my little sister and being older I think when I get older and pass away will your kids and siblings be in good hands and I’m very thankful that she’s in good hands - so I couldn’t ask for more.Jeremy also quizzed Samantha about whether she was jealous of Meghan because of her success as a top American actress and because she married a prince.She replied: Jealously, I hear that and it’s strange – it doesn’t really make sense. I’m so much older than she is and I had my opportunities and made my choices, you love your siblings and want them to do well.“I was more hurt for my father . I was broken-hearted by the way things turned out. At the end of the day people are people that’s the way I’ve always seen it, as long as she’s happy that was what we wanted.Describing Thomas current condition after his heart attack, she added: He’s 74, his breathing is challenged.All things considered, our days are always numbered but his perhaps more so.”She also said she decided to take social media to discuss her sister and call her names including Cruella de Vil because she wanted to “protect” her father and give him a voice because he was becoming “ignored”.Samantha also said that she would keep any discussion she has with her sister “private” and would not give an interview to disclose what they talked about.Last month Samantha wrote on Twitter: I am not candy coating anything anymore! The DUCHASS should be humane to our father who has given her everything,.. and this media crap can stop!He was the one who was always there for her. Fake waves and smiles can stop. The duchASS can bow to the daddy.

title: pregnant mother asda shop delivery driver refused help
story: Amy Natasha Botten, from Feltham, West London, was left breathless and swaying from side to side as she struggled to collect her goods.Video captures the driver raising his voice at Amy who begs him to help her with the last bit because my little boy is up there crying his eyes out.Amy said: Can you not be a decent person? I am heavily pregnant. You are just going to walk off and leave me with this now?The driver, who cuts her off, replied: See, before you taking little much. One time I go. Okay no problem... but not like this.Amy also questioned why there were no more bags that she could put her goods in. But he shrugged his shoulders and continued to pack up his empty crates.Amy later posted the video of her ordeal on Facebook with the caption: This shouldnt be happening to anyone......bad health, lonely and elderly, disabled, pregnant!!It should NOT BE HAPPENING. Its called HOME delivery.I just had to carry £200 monthly shop up two flights of stairs alone, pregnant with pelvic problems.No choice but to leave my son on his own crying.Feltham Asda gave me a bottle of champagne and some flowers and couldnt apologise enough for the driver not doing his job .She was quick to highlight Asdas commitment in which drivers are required to offer to take shopping into customers homes.Sun Online has contacted Asda for comment.

title: landlord grimsby west marsh house mess family
story: Along with leaving the house in a state of disarray, the evicted family apparently still owe £1,700 in unpaid rent for the Grimsby property.Landlord Garry told GrimsbyLive that the family had ruined the kitchen and that 50 bags of waste had to be hauled from the house.The kitchen floor had nearly vanished under the piles of bags filled to the brim with filthy clothes, food containers caked in mould and white counters so stained that they had turned brown.It seemed the family had destroyed the garden too by leaving it to vastly overgrow with nettles and brambles and littering it with broken doors, cupboards and household waste.Carpets had been ripped up, doors were hanging off their hinges, electrical sockets had been knocked out of the walls and the bathroom was completely trashed.Garry said that he was forced to refurbish the entire house and that even the ceiling was covered in grime.According to the disgruntled landlord, the family were on Universal Credit and that this isnt the first time hes had issues with tenants on housing benefits.He was forced to evict one of his previous tenants, who was also on Universal Credit who owed him thousands in rent.His property manager, Anne, has said that it has completely put him off renting to people on benefits and that they have had numerous problems with them going into arrears.She said: Many times when a tenant goes onto the benefits system, there is no communication with us as landlords, and for the first few months we often get no rent paid.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: philip hammond tory conference speech labour
story: The Chancellor told Tory party conference that Jeremy Corbyn offers no future for Britain and urged voters not to be tricked into supporting him.And he warned that the only way to combat Labour is to set out a robust Conservative agenda - not just offer watered-down versions of left-wing policies.During his conference speech in Birmingham, Mr Hammond said: “This country now faces a choice.“A choice between the seductive simplicity of the Brave New World of Corbyn and McDonnell’s populism, where the narrative is all about easy answers and our pragmatism, which is sceptical of ideologues, which starts with the real world we live in, and seeks to make it better and recognises that there are no shortcuts and no free lunches on the road to a better Britain.He added that capitalist ideas are “rejected out of hand by Corbyn and McDonnell in favour of the failed and faded ideologies of socialism - not because they believe they would enhance economic growth, but because they don’t care about economic growth”.Mr Hammond continued: “Because they are more interested in re-distributing wealth than in creating more of it.“Because they value political ideology above real world solutions for real people.“All they do, is look it up in the Socialist manual. Railways? Nationalise them.“Wealth? Confiscate it. Run out of money? Just borrow more.“Answers from a discredited ideology that will never solve real-world problems.”And he finished his crowd-pleasing speech by saying: Corbyn’s plan offers no future for Britain. And it is our duty to provide a better answer.To make the case for the long term over the short term, for the substantial over the superficial, for evolution over revolution.He claimed Labours extreme plans deserve a response and warned it wont be enough to offer up milder versions of the left-wing policies favoured by Mr Corbyn.Mr Hammond said: We will not outbid Corbyn with short-term gimmicks that cause long-term damage we will not outspend him with reckless borrowing.But the Chancellor risked sparking a backlash from his own activists as he insisted Britain will have to remain closely tied to Europe after Brexit.He said: Whatever the outcome, Europe will remain firmly anchored just a few miles off the coast of Kent.Europe remains, by far, our biggest market. And after 45 years of membership, Britain’s economy has shaped itself around that fact.Mr Hammond predicted a deal idend which will see the UKs economy boom once we strike a trade deal with the EU.And he laid out a series of policies to boost the economy including:Labour hit back at his attack on them - Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell said: The Chancellor’s speech confirmed the bankrupt state of the Tory party, increasingly irrelevant and cut off from the real day to day le most people experience.“The Tories are bereft of any fresh ideas, forced to resort to a half-hearted filching of policies from others and desperately trying to revive long outdated slogans.

title: food waste supermarkets meals for the poor michael gove conservative conference
story: The Environment Secretary will today launch a £1billion plan to use food set for the skip to provide 250 million meals for the needy.Those who could get access to the extra food include kids in breakfast clubs, elderly people in old peoples homes, disabled groups and the homeless.Mr Gove said today ahead of the announcement: Nobody wants to see good food go to waste. It harms our environment, it’s bad for business – and it’s morally indefensible.Every year, around 100,000 tonnes of readily available and perfectly edible food is never eaten. This has got to change.Supermarkets will work together with charities and the Government to save the food from the bin in the £15million one-year scheme.The plans will focus on fresh produce rather than cupboard dry food - and junk food wont be included.The UK throws away around £13billion worth of worthy food every single year.That works out at a cost of £440 per household.Campaigners say efforts to tackle waste have stalled, with 7.3million tons of food thrown away in 2015, compared with seven million tons in 2012.

title: stelios haji ioannou easyjet sues netflix easy

title: pm must prove to conservatives she can strike brexit deal
story: That speech, notable for the "citizens of nowhere" refrain, set up expectations within her own party for an uncompromising hard or clean Brexit, and yet it also set up so publicly the red lines that have led to the current state of EU rejection.So when Boris Johnson decided to blanket the start of the Conservative conference with suggestions not just that Chequers is wrong, or dead, but that it was "deranged" and "preposterous", the origins of that betrayal narrative can be rooted back to her speech two years ago when she communicated that the UK would not be subject to European Court of Justice jurisdiction.:: Theresa May hints she could compromise on Chequers plan in Brexit talksChequers maintains some forms of that jurisdiction, at least indirectly in the market for goods and agriculture.A reasonable compromise, it can and will be argued. But was this predictable direction of travel really signalled two years ago?Likewise, red lines were further detailed at the subsequent Lancaster House speech on not joining the European Economic Area or reforming a customs union with the EU.     At that point the PM changed her language from wanting and expecting "frictionless" trade to "as frictionless as possible".At Chequers, she embraced again the promise of post-Brexit "frictionless" trade as the aim of her deal - for both the Northern Ireland border and for manufacturers with "just-in-time" supply chains, such as car-makers.The very point of Chequers is to try to achieve frictionless trade but outside the framework that created it in the first place - the single market and customs union.,targeting:" data-targeting-strnativekey="" data-targeting-platform="" data-tag="" data-component-name="sdc-site-mpu" aria-label="Advertisement" id="mpu-inline-mobile" data-tolerance="2"

title: un appy days as divided tories meet at conference
story: Well, security on the app did not stay in place, though to be fair, it was resolved swtly. "It's sorted - and in time for the conference!" Mr Lewis told me proudly.Some problems can be sorted quickly, it seems. Not Brexit, though.It is doubtful whether the Conservatives will be any more united on the PM's Chequers plan when they leave here on Wednesday than they are as they arrive.     After his 4,500-word eve-of-conference onslaught on the PM's Brexit policy in The Daily , followed up by TV interviews, Boris Johnson's "chuck Chequers" rally on Tuesday evening - hours before the PM's big conference speech - will be the box office highlight of this conference.Boris has staged these rallies at Tory conferences before. He is greeted like a rock star with the same sort of adulation Jeremy Corbyn receives at his rallies during Labour conferences.The conference slogan this year - on enormous blue banners - contains just one word: "Opportunity", with eight pledges underneath.     The order of these pledges is interesting, reflecting Tory priorities which some in the party will claim are in the wrong order.They are, in this order::: The best Brexit deal for Britain:: A long-term plan for the NHS:: A strong economy:: Improving education:: Protecting the environment:: Tackling injustices:: Global Britain:: More homes.Is building more homes, really the party's lowest priority?As  managing Boris's bombshell this week wasn't bad enough, it was reported that Mr Lewis was planning to brandish his phone and sing the praises of the app during his speech welcoming the activists at the opening of the conference on Sunday. Not true, I'm told emphatically. Probably just as well!The other Sunday highlights, during a session on Global Britain, will be speeches by the Brexiteer International Trade Secretary Liam Fox, another Brexiteer, the International Development Secretary Penny Mordaunt, followed by the new Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt.Amid all the speculation about how long Theresa May will survive as PM, Penny Mordaunt is seen by many as a potential candidate for the leadership from the Tory right. Jeremy Hunt's odds have also shortened dramatically since his fairly gaffe-free start as foreign secretary.,targeting:" data-targeting-strnativekey="" data-targeting-platform="" data-tag="" data-component-name="sdc-site-mpu" aria-label="Advertisement" id="mpu-inline-mobile" data-tolerance="2"

title: whos auditioning for the conservative leadership in birmingham this week
story: :: Dominic Raab - The Brexit secretary is due to speak from the main conference stage on Monday and, other than that, he is only listed to appear at one fringe event. However,  he is interested in raising his profile for a possible tilt at the leadership, Mr Raab will no doubt consider his efforts are better spent concentrating on negotiations with the EU rather than schmoozing party members in Birmingham. As one of the few prominent Leave campaigners to support Mrs May's Chequers plan, Mr Raab is having to deal with claims from hardline Brexiteers he has betrayed the cause in favour of a cabinet position. He has also been sidelined in favour of top civil servant Olly Robbins, with Mr Raab's Brexit department no longer directly responsible for negotiating the UK's orce. However,  Mr Raab does help secure a successful Brexit outcome that the Tories can end up uniting around, surely he would then become a serious leadership candidate. :: Penny Mordaunt - The international development secretary is due to speak from the main conference stage on Sunday and is also listed to speak at three fringe events. Ms Mordaunt made a name for herself during the EU referendum as a prominent member of the Vote Leave campaign. She backs the prime minister's Chequers plan by virtue of being in government, although she has been conspicuously quiet in voicing that support publicly. This has helped fuel reports she is on the verge of quitting the cabinet unless Mrs May changes tack. In her cabinet role she has led the government response to the Oxfam sex scandal, while her additional women and equalities brief has seen her generate headlines through her support for legalising abortion in Northern Ireland. She also recently became the first government minister to use sign language during a speech in the House of Commons. If the Tories wanted a third female leader in their history, the former Splash! reality TV show star might be in pole position.,targeting:" data-targeting-strnativekey="" data-targeting-platform="" data-tag="" data-component-name="sdc-site-mpu" aria-label="Advertisement" id="mpu-inline-mobile" data-tolerance="2":: Theresa May? - Not many Tories give the prime minister much hope of leading the party into the next general election, which is scheduled in 2022. title: chancellor philip hammond claims britain
story: NewsChancellor Philip Hammond claims Britain will BOOM with a Brexit 'deal idend' in wildly optimistic Tory conference speechIn a huge hostage to fortune, the Chancellor claimed the economy will soar as soon as the Prime Minister brings back an as-yet-unknown package from BrusselsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor12:58, 1 OCT 2018Updated13:21, 1 OCT 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/politics/video/philip-hammond-claims-therell-brexit-13340684,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPhilip Hammond today claimed services like the NHS will get a 'Brexit deal idend' within WEEKS in a wildly bullish speech to the Tory party conference. In a huge hostage to fortune, the Chancellor claimed the economy will boom as soon as the Prime Minister brings back an as-yet-unknown package from Brussels - which MPs could still vote down. The new plea was aimed squarely at Tory Brexiteers who are threatening to vote down the deal Mrs May hopes to bring back in just a few weeks' time. It is the pro-Remain Chancellor's version of the much-disputed claim that Brexit itself will bring a 'idend' for the NHS - after 2020, when payments to Brussels are cut. Mr Hammond has been known as one of the most gloomy ministers on Brexit. Only this morning he admitted firms were sitting on their hands due to deadlock in talks with Brussels. Yet addressing Conservative members in Birmingham today, he claimed: I'm going to stick my neck out here today and make a prediction to you - that when the Prime Minister gets a deal agreed there will be a boost to our economic growth.  A 'deal idend', which we will share in line with our balanced approach between keeping taxes low, supporting public services, reducing the deficit, and investing in Britain's future. But Mr Hammond also said preparations for no deal are continuing. I will maintain enough fiscal firepower in my locker to support our economy  that happens, he said. In a wide-ranging speech that quoted Margaret Thatcher and free market economist Adam Smith, Mr Hammond vowed not to outbid Jeremy Corbyn's Labour party and said Tories must reclaim 21st century capitalism. Ripping off Labour's 'for the many not the few' slogan, he declared Tories must reassure the very many who will worry about what new technologies mean for their job security - worry that the gains will be made by the few.  And he said Conservatives are faced with an “urgent mission” to persuade voters to avoid “dangerous and seductive populism led by Jeremy Corbyn - who is totally unfit to govern this country. The Chancellor declared: We will not outbid Corbyn with short-term gimmicks that cause long-term damage. We will not outspend him with reckless borrowing. We will not promise the illusory utopia he offers. Because, as those who have tried it have shown time and time again, it is based on a lie and it always ends in tears. He added: Corbyn boasts that Labour are a government in waiting. Well, I say let’s keep him waiting - this year, next year and every year. Elsewhere Mr Hammond announced a &pound125 million package to change the distribution of the Tories' 'apprenticeship levy' after concerns over how well the system was working. Measures include allowing large employers to transfer up to 25% of their apprenticeship levy funds to businesses in their supply chain from April next year.  He also announced &pound100million for a 'National Retraining Scheme' in partnership with the CBI and the TUC.  The Chancellor also warned robots will be the biggest threat on the horizon - and a huge opportunity. In the next decade or so, Articial Intelligence, self-driving cars, personalized medicine, virtual reality, advanced robotics and many, many other cutting-edge developments will all begin to transform our lives, he said. A future where cars don’t pollute, and we’ve all but eliminated traffic accidents Where you are able to order and 3D print a product at home, instead of waiting for it to be delivered Where cancer is tamed, so that fewer of us have to go through the heartache of losing a loved one to this cruel disease. All of this is science fact not fiction. Despite his reputation - and telling a string of jokes that no one laughed at - the Chancellor insisted: I am an optimist. I've heard some call me glass half full Phil. It depends who's buying.

title: defiant message tory conference stop
story: NewsopinionMy defiant message to Tory conference: stop the austerity and give people some bloody helpThe Mirror's Ros Wynne-Jones told the Conservatives what le is really like in 21st century Britain. You can read her speech hereShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRos Wynne JonesReal Britain columnist19:00, 30 SEP 2018Updated20:26, 30 SEP 2018NewsopinionRos Wynne-Jones confronted the Tories on the rise in rough sleepers "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThank you very much for having me here today to the Conservative Conference fringe. I have to confess it’s not a place I’ve been to before. But  we’re to change the lives of any of the people I write about, you are the people I need to convince that things desperately need changing in our country. And I’d like to thank you for trying to listen to voices outside of your own political mainstream. All of our politics on every side suffer from the silos we are trapped in and can’t climb out of. So, thank you. It’s always a pleasure to be in Birmingham, and particularly relevant to what I’m going to say today as it’s the city we started our Wigan Pier Project from. For the past two years we’ve been retracing George Orwell’s Road to Wigan Pier and he set out from here in the Midlands.  When we began our journey in January 2017, I’d read about the growing cardboard city in Birmingham, and I came to interview homeless people at a breakfast service. It was a bitterly cold morning when I got off the train from London, so cold that my feet froze on the walk from the station, and when I got to the breakfast place there was a queue twice round the block. All the homeless people were talking about a young man who had died overnight in sub-zero temperatures. When I found the place he’d died, a little carpark on John Bright Street, less than 15 minutes’ walk from here, someone had already taken the warm and dry patch he’d died on – dragging their filthy duvet over a broken-down cardboard box. The people we went on to interview over the next few days and weeks, could literally break your heart. A veteran in a wheelchair who had been RPGd. A man who told us about all the homeless people he knew who had thrown themselves off buildings. An amazing homeless band called the Dissenters. Who knew that ‘Broken Britain’ wasn’t a slogan but an ambition? No-one in this room can deny that homelessness in this country has grown exponentially in this country since 2010 when the Conservative Party came to power and David Cameron announced the ‘Age of Austerity’. Just walk round here tonight for a few minutes and you’ll see homeless people all over the city, just as you’ll see them in London and Manchester and Liverpool and Blackpool and Hastings and yes, even in Windsor, where a Tory council wanted them removed for spoiling the Royal Wedding. So, no it’s not just Birmingham, but there’s still something amazing about how the Conservative Party always comes and holds its party conference here. Something geographically appealing about its centrality I imagine. And yet. Look at the Midlands: Birmingham City Council’s budget has been slashed by an eyewatering 40 per cent. By 2025 the Council budget will have lost three-quarters of a billion pounds. Look at the crisis at Birmingham Prison this summer. The collapse at Northamptonshire County Council. Recent figures showing that childcare costs have risen nine times faster than wages in the West Midlands since 2008. The fact that yesterday a group of Birmingham home care workers, mostly low paid women, lead a march through the city. I know it’s must be easy to dismiss these people as Marxist agitators – but what  they are just homecare workers whose services have been devastated by privatisation? Who work under minimum wage because they won’t leave old people in wet pads, but who work for skeleton companies owned by hedge funds? When George Orwell set off from Birmingham in 1936, it was because he understood there were two Britains. A well-off Britain that was more than comfortable. And a Britain barely surviving in the industrial north and Midlands. What he came to see, as he travelled through the north, I believe, was something even more serious – that the sweat of one Britain was enabling the comfort of the other Britain. That’s never been more true in our Britain today – where one person’s ability to order a perfectly chilled bottle of wine instantly and cheaply from Amazon Prime, relies on the sweat of another person toiling in a windowless workhouse. Are these people left behind? Those people working in reinvented Victorian insecurity? Those people for whom the inflated housing market inflated that bit too far? For whom the welfare safety net has been slashed beyond recognition? The people working three jobs who are still sometimes skipping meals so their children can eat? Like Orwell, I think we need to question language at every turn. Austerity did this, of course it did – but it was enabled by language, by words serving a political narrative. It’s language – the language of strivers and scroungers, the language of racist ide and rule, separating the working classes so they are isible by the colour of their skin, that has led to this mess in the first place. The repulsive language of Leave and the patronising, hectoring language of Remain. So, I have to start by asking what you mean by ‘Left Behind Britain’? Do you mean some people weren’t All In It Together after all? Left behind sounds like someone that missed the bus. Maybe they were a bit too slow to get on board. Maybe they weren’t modern people, stuck in their ways. The angry, jittery, poverty-stricken, Brexit-y parts of Britain aren’t ‘left behind’. They have been Held Back from getting on the bus in the first place. As a direct result of policies that have been developed at Tory conferences like this one. By the attack on their support through welfare reform. By the cuts to their schools and the services for kids that need extra help. By the closure of the Sure Start centres that used to help level the early years playing fields. By the closure of the libraries where they used to search for jobs, and borrow books and do their homework. By the lack of hope inherent in walking down boarded up high streets every day. You can call them Just About Managing. I call them in crisis, in debt, and incandescent. Anyway – two years ago, an unnecessary vote called by a Conservative Prime Minister who was trying to outwit a flank of his party, offered Held Back people a lightning rod moment.  It still might not have been defining, but the Tory-led Remain campaign pushed them further and further to the wall. Threatening them. Bullying them. Filling the airwaves with the spiralising classes – the patronising Smoothie Millionaires. It was the worst run political campaign in living memory that learned nothing from the insurgent ‘Yes’ campaign that nearly won in Scotland, and everything from the ‘No’ campaign that nearly lost. No wonder millions of people decided it was the moment to speak up. Did we listen? No. Did we hell.  The wall between the silos has actually thickened. Leaving screaming voices desperate to be heard, shut out again, pushed ever further from the centre and into the arms of St Tommy Robinson. In 1936, Orwell watched the same phenomenon, encountering Oswald Mosley on his Road to Wigan Pier. It’s kind of beautul in its circularity. The poorest people vote against the EU that protected their rights and now the richest people will get even richer and capitalism ever more unfettered and rampant. Who wins? Extreme capitalism. The people who funded Vote Leave. Meanwhile in a Britain just outside this shiny city centre, high streets where libraries once stood stand empty, and homeless people huddle in shop doorways and mental health services are closed down and cafes have been replaced by betting shops and cash converters where people queue at 8am on a Monday morning holding their worldly goods in cardboard boxes tied with string. These people haven’t been ‘left behind’. It’s far more sinister than that. The people who did the least to cause the banking crisis have been made to pay for it. We weren’t all in it together, not even close. They’ve not been Left Behind – they’ve been evaded, by those companies who not only evade their taxes but evade their workers’ rights too by the use of shady agency companies straight out of Charles Dickens. They have been Held Back by welfare ‘reform’ – a term I use in its loosest sense. Because nothing better has come from the Bedroom Tax or the shambles of Personal Independence Payments – or from the bitter pill of Universal Credit. There’s no point saying that the principle of UC isn’t a bad one, when it contains at its very core a deep cut – a five to eight week wait with no money coming in.  I can’t go into everything that’s wrong with the government’s welfare reform programme in 5 minutes. But in its simplest terms –  you go to the foodbank – there’s one less than half a mile from here – and ask what people are doing in there you will 99 per cent likely be told one of three things. Benefit delays, sanctions, or insecure work. None of them an accident. They were part of a devised political plan. To make Austerity work there had to be human collateral, and that has been the poorest and most powerless and vulnerable people in society. There’s even been a particularly nasty narrative alongside it, the scroungers narrative. Who would care about what’s happening to them? The hostile environment created by policies that came out of this conference, was not just for immigrants. It’s your party that has been hijacked by extremists.  If you go to the Easterhouse estate, where Iain Duncan Smith wept, and had his Damascene moment and ask the people there, as I have, whether any of them – ANY – are better off you will be extremely lucky to find a single soul. Even the bloke who showed him round was ashamed. That is the level of total failure and misery I am asking you to confront today. Meanwhile, insecure work is not a fact of le but a symptom of how the 1950s sunny uplands maidens-on-bicycles capitalism beloved of this conference has failed all but wealthiest in this country. Enabled by another myth – that of ‘trickle down wealth’. Funnily enough it was a trickle, a trickle too small to see. But it cascaded at the top, where the rich have got richer and richer and richer since the crash. It’s not the 1950s any more.

title: foreign secretary jeremy hunt sparks
story: NewsForeign Secretary Jeremy Hunt sparks fury from Foreign Office experts by comparing EU to Soviet Russia Mr Hunt accused Brussels of seeking to "punish" Britain for wanting to leave the EU and compared it to the Soviet Union trying to stop its citizens leavingShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent10:25, 1 OCT 2018Updated12:23, 1 OCT 2018NewsJeremy Hunt made the bizarre comments at his speech to Tory Party conference "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTwo of the Foreign Office's most senior former mandarins have turned on Jeremy Hunt, after the Foreign Secretary compared the EU to the Soviet Union. In his keynote speech to the Conservative conference in Birmingham, Mr Hunt accused Brussels of seeking to punish Britain for wanting to leave the EU and compared it to the Soviet Union trying to stop its citizens leaving.  The comment was denounced as unworthy of a British Foreign Secretary by the former head of Foreign Office civil servants Lord Ricketts, while his successor as Permanent Secretary Sir Simon Fraser described it as a shocking failure of judgment.  Meanwhile, Latvia's ambassador to the UK retorted that the EU had brought her country prosperity, equality, growth, respect after decades in which the Soviet Union ruined the lives of its people. In his speech on Sunday, the Foreign Secretary recalled a visit to Latvia, during which he observed how the Baltic state had developed into a modern democracy, part of both NATO and the EU after breaking free of the Soviet Union. And he asked: What happened to the confidence and ideals of the European dream? The EU was set up to protect freedom. It was the Soviet Union that stopped people leaving.  The lesson from history is clear:  you turn the EU club into a prison, the desire to get out won't diminish it will grow, and we won't be the only prisoner that will want to escape.   Lord Ricketts, who was the Foreign Office's most senior civil servant from 2006-10 before serving as National Security Adviser and ambassador to France, responded on Twitter : This rubbish is unworthy of a British Foreign Secretary.  The EU isn't a Soviet-style prison. Its legal order has brought peace and prosperity after a century of war. Our decision to leave was always going to leave us worse off. The only punishment is the self-inflicted iety. And Sir Simon Fraser, who led Britain's diplomats from 2010-15 and is now vice-chair of foreign affairs think-tank Chatham House, said: I agree with Lord Ricketts, my predecessor as Permanent Secretary. Whatever you think about Brexit , shocking failure of judgement for British Foreign Secretary to compare European Union with Soviet Union.  Latvian ambassador Baiba Braze said: Soviets killed, deported, exiled and imprisoned 100 thousands of Latvia's inhabitants after the illegal occupation in 1940, and ruined lives of 3 generations, while the EU has brought prosperity, equality, growth, respect. Ms Braze later appeared to play down any rt with Mr Hunt, sending a second tweet thanking him for his warm words and memories about his visit to Latvia and UK's contribution to our freedom in his speech.
