story: NewsJacob Rees-Mogg calls African country 'the People's Republic of Jam Jar or something'The hardline Brexiteer chief claimed, without evidence, that Britain wouldn't have to pay a orce bill  we left without a dealShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter21:14, 30 SEP 2018Updated07:17, 1 OCT 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/video/jacob-rees-mogg-calls-african-13338340,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJacob Rees-Mogg referred to an African country as “the people’s republic of jam jar or something”, in a speech to Conservative Party Conference. The hardline Brexiteer made the remark to a packed crowd at a fringe meeting at the party’s annual gathering in Birmingham. He was referring to the Great Socialist People's Libyan Arab Jamahiriya, which was the name of Libya under Colonel Gaddafi. Labour MP and Best for Britain champion Alex Sobel MP said: This not only shows the same sort of casual racism Boris Johnson has displayed but also a disdain for the rest of the World which would leave us isolated and economically eviscerated  he is allowed his hard Brexit  Mr Rees-Mogg was telling party faithful he thought using the term “people’s vote” sounded totalitarian. He said: “All the countries who are least interested in their people call themselves ‘people's’, don’t they? “So the People’s Republic of China? Oh, that’s communist. “And the People’s Republic of…jam jar, or something like that, of Libya, was what it was called when Colonel Gaddafi was in charge.” The term Jamahiriya roughly translates as “state of the masses”. Lib Dem frontbencher Christine Jardine said: “This sort of remark is becoming too common from the Brexiteers, coming as it does in the wake of Boris’s recent burka jibes.  Insulting other people is not the way I want my country represented and the public see it for what it is, petty politics.” He went on to declare Theresa May’s Chequers deal “the deadest of dead ducks in thunderstorms.” Speaking at a rally organised by pro-Brexit website Brexit Central, Mr Rees-Mogg said: “I went to Chequers once. “I went to Chequers when Ted Heath was Prime Minister. He gave me Garibaldi biscuits. “I was three at the time, and I thought very highly of Mr Heath because of these Garibaldi biscuits. You see how easily children’s opinions are formed. “But however many Garibaldi biscuits I was given, I would not support Chequers as it is today.” Mr Rees-Mogg said neither the Conservative Party, the Labour Party or the EU would vote for Mrs May’s Chequers deal.

title: tory esther mcvey suggests partys
story: NewsTory Esther McVey suggests her own party's benefit cuts are "fake news" in shameless conference speechThe Work and Pensions Secretary launched her attack despite cuts being well-documented by experts and her predecessor Iain Duncan Smith.Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor11:18, 1 OCT 2018Updated11:36, 1 OCT 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/politics/video/esther-mcvey-says-tory-benefit-13339619,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTory welfare chief Esther McVey today suggested her own party's benefit cuts are fake news in a shameless party conference speech. The Work and Pensions Secretary launched an arrogant attack on Labour and social media - despite cuts being well-documented by think tanks and her predecessor Iain Duncan Smith. Most working-age benefits are frozen for four years from 2016/17 to 2019/20 - a cut to families' real income. The government's own 2015 Budget said this would cut &pound4billion a year from the benefits bill. Meanwhile, new benefit Universal Credit is widely agreed to be less generous than it was designed to be thanks to cuts by ex-Chancellor George Osborne. Its founder, Tory Iain Duncan Smith, said &pound2billion more must be put in to restore it - while the National Audit Office has cast doubt on its claim to make work pay. Tories have axed housing benefit for under-22s, only to U-turn and ditch the policy. They've introduced a &pound20,000 cap on household benefits. And hundreds of thousands of previous claimants have been denied disability benefits under the new Personal Independence Payment. Yet Ms McVey - who has herself been forced to correct misleading statements about benefits - appeared to suggest all these facts were fake news because the total amount of money put into thebenefits system has gone up.  She told Tory members in Birmingham: If you were to believe everything you heard from Labour or read on social media you'd think we were somehow letting down the most vulnerable in society - especially disabled people. However, those who say we are cutting budgets are peddling fake news. So here’s the real news - we have never spent more on those with disabilities and long-term health conditions. We spend over &pound50billion a year, up &pound9billion on 2010. Ms McVey said she became a Conservative to stand against the ugly, destructive, Marxist, Militant, socialists of the past.  Blasting the pro-Corbyn campaign group, she told members: Momentum is the modern day Militant - and remember there are three M's in Momentum - Militant, Militant, Militant. Can you imagine it, this country with Corbyn, McDonnell and Abbott at the helm? It would be a political nightmare, with Labour doing what it always does - leaving office with higher unemployment than it inherited. She added: Remember what John McDonnell said about me? That I should be lynched. Well he picked on the wrong woman!  .     In a new policy, Ms McVey announced the Citizens Advice Bureau is set to receive &pound39million to help Universal Credit claimants under the Universal Support scheme. The cash will fund advisers to help claimants get their first payment on time and be ready to manage it when it arrives.

title: what tory brexit going look
story: NewsopinionThis is what the Tory Brexit is going to look likeThere's bad news for borders, badgers and BorisShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist12:31, 1 OCT 2018Updated12:34, 1 OCT 2018Newsopinion"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThere are 179 days until Brexit, they've got a full tank of prats, half a pack of loons, they're doomed and they're wearing blue rosettes. Welcome to the Conservative Party conference of 2018, where the Tories are trying to pretend they can organise a knees-up that doesn't somehow end in whacking themselves in the testicles.  It's day one, and they've already failed. Their Great Blond Hope has not only been victim of a Big Daddy splash by Lord Digby Jones, he's been impersonated by Phil 'Voldemort' Hammond and had his ideas characterised as not much good by David 'Mine Are No Better' Davis.  We are now uncomfortably close to the arbitrary date for leaving the European Union, chosen by a Prime Minister who herself was chosen because she wasn't someone else, and as is the way with things on horizons it looks worryingly like an out-of-control hydrogen explosion.  We all know what's happened - the referendum supposed to uny the Tories has caused them to turn on each other like cannibals who gave up chlorinated chicken for Lent, the question supposed to be settled for a generation remains unanswered, and Theresa May is still PM primarily because she isn't someone else.  So what is Brexit going to look like, under the Tories? 1. Project Oh Dear   Jeremy Hunt is a man who has more in common with an Anglepoise lamp than the rest of the human race. He can be pointed, turned on, and turned off again, but usually fails to illuminate anyone. He is now second-favourite to be Prime Minister next year, which should be adequate proof of just how boked the Tories are.  Boris is trolling, Sajid and Gavin are manoeuvring, Chris Grayling is in a siding outside Melton Mowbray and Hunt - a man who, the Leveson Inquiry heard, tried to hide behind trees to avoid journalists while still being visible to them - is now, let me say it again, one of the favourites. It's a bit like saying the green Opal Fruit is your favourite. Or that the USSR, which invaded countries that tried to leave it and killed millions, is just like the EU, which negotiates, even with people who don't know what they're doing. 2. Project You Can't Be Serious  Having toured the country in a bus promising to give our EU subscription to the NHS, the Tories have since said: a we'll still have to pay a subscription b it will be higher, without a rebate  c by the way, we'll be cutting &pound2.7bn off the NHS  Today the spiritual leader of the Brextremists has suggested we spend our foreign aid budget on saving elephants, because they remind him of Beethoven's Fth Symphony. Hang the education projects, stuff the small-scale charities who exist entirely because of foreign aid, and let's get all worked up about the 70 pence in every &pound100 national profit that we spend on foreigners. Boo hiss to foreigners! Elephants are British! Wait, what? 3. Project Is This Really The Best You Could Do  Brexit, the Tories are assuring us and their donors, will mean a bonfire of unnecessary rules and regulations about meaningless, bureaucratic tripe like child car seats, not getting killed at work and hiding your money from the taxman.  It gives us a chance to set our own rules such as only banning dangerous cladding 15 months after it burned 72 people alive, and only  it's on new buildings, which means all the people living in older properties can go sizzle.  It also won't matter  you sleep surrounded by highly-flammable material on the sixth floor, or  you don't have a sprinkler system, or the fire exits are blocked or non-existent. After Brexit, you won't want to live anyway. 4. Project Genuine Fear  The government of the UK is trying to exit a union it doesn't want while protecting one that it does. To do so they are relying on a referendum they say must be respected, while ignoring a referendum they say must be over-ridden.  All the people concerned were told beforehand that Brexit would spell the end of the Good Friday Agreement, a hard-won peace in Northern Ireland, and possibly the end of the Union altogether. That they have now, 6 months from doom, had this explained to them again by a comedian shows just what a bad joke the Tories are.  Patrick Kielty's dad was murdered by the Ulster Freedom Fighters for exposing their organised crime. The Tories' border solution involves asking those self-same people to pretend there's a border where there isn't one, and file paperwork well in advance before smuggling guns, drugs and people across 300 miles of hedge that we can't police. Laugh? You'll die. 5. Project It All Onto Someone Else   Presiding over economic chaos? Watching John Lewis go down the pan, the world turn against you, and Jacob Rees-Mogg destroying all his own suggestions by moving his investment funds to the EU and trying to get a trade deal with the People's Republic of Jam Jar Or Something Like That?   Well, why not shoot some more badgers. Not in the head, that's too quick. Kneecap them and watch them suffer. Burn some cattle, bankrupt some farmers, blame it all on the EU's crazy rules about bovine TB which isn't harmless so long as you pasteurise your milk, mostly doesn't kill cows and could easily be stopped with a vaccine  only we could be bothered.  When someone says 'but Brexit means we can abandon these rules! Save the badgers!' point out we still have to abide by EU rules  we want to sell beef, milk or cheese to the EU. And don't, for heaven's sake, let anyone say that the only way to change those rules is to, er, remain in the EU.  With a Tory Brexit, hard or soft, you're looking at Jeremy Hunt being in charge while making swingeing NHS cuts, making it quite the worst reboot of a franchise since Indiana Jones And The Hospital Of Doom.  You'll see people burning in another tower block before long, a fresh wave of terrorism when we haven't dealt with the current one, and Tories blaming badgers, migrants, and anything else that moved because, after Brexit, they'll no longer be able to blame the EU. The Tories have spent the past 40 years blaming Europe for all the things they cocked up themselves. Without the EU, people are going to blame the Tories. Which is why their days are numbered.

title: asda delivery driver dumps pregnant
story: NewsAsda delivery driver dumps pregnant mum's shopping at bottom of tower block stairs and REFUSES to help carry itAmy Natasha Brown was left out of breath as she carried the shopping up to the second floor while her son was left alone screaming in the flatShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAbigail O'Leary13:17, 1 OCT 2018Updated14:09, 1 OCT 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/uk-news/video/asda-delivery-driver-dumps-heavily-13340527,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn Asda delivery driver dumped a heavily pregnant woman's shopping at the bottom of the stairs before REFUSING to help her carry it to her second-floor flat. Amy Natasha Botten, a mum-of-one, shared footage of the incident Facebook, showing her puffing and out of breath as she carried her goods up the stairs. As her little boy cries in the background, Amy can be heard begging the driver to help her. The mum, who uploaded the footage on Saturday, can then be heard asking why her shopping isn't bagged after filming the driver dumping loose items on the floor and telling him she's heavily pregnant. The short clips starts with Amy walking into her flat trying to calm her son, clearly out of breath from the two storey walk.  She then walks down the stairs before asking the driver: I thought you said you put everything in bags for me? The driver then replies with: There's no more bags. Amy goes on to ask: Can you not help me with this last little bit because my little boy is up there crying his eyes out? Can you not hear my little boy crying his eyes out? Can you not even be a decent person, I am heavily pregnant. The driver repeatedly refuses to help Amy with her shopping, before gathering the delivery crates and walking off.  Amy then adds: So you're just going to walk off and leave me with this. In a Facebook post, Amy said: This shouldn’t be happening to anyone, bad health, lonely and elderly, disabled, pregnant!! It should NOT BE HAPPENING. It’s called HOME delivery. I just had to carry &pound200 monthly shop up two flights of stairs alone, pregnant with pelvic problems. No choice but to leave my son on his own crying. Feltham asda gave me a bottle of champagne and some flowers and couldn’t apologise enough for the driver not doing his job. .

title: autistic boy 12 pelted toxic
story: NewsAutistic boy, 12, pelted with 'toxic slime' by bullies causing agonising burns to his neckJack Poore was cycling to school when the mystery substance was thrown at himShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByDaniel HammondEleanor Perkins12:46, 1 OCT 2018NewsJack felt like his neck 'was on fire' "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn autistic 12-year-old has been left in agony and with 'burns' on his neck after bullies pelted him with a mystery toxic slime. Jack Poore was cycling to school when he was hit with a mystery acidic substance - thought to be mixed with toy slime. His mother, Tara, 37, received a panicked call from her son and immediately thought that Jack had been the victim of an acid attack. The schoolboy wiped the sludge from his neck and fell to the grass - with his body feeling like 'it was on fire'.  He was able to make it into his school reception, where staff were able to prise the rest of the 'green slime' off his neck area. School staff gave Jack medical assistance - but days later his neck still burns and he was left with a red 'blotchy mark' and 'tingles'. Tara, from Margate, Kent, said: He phoned me in state, saying he was in agony - he was crying, saying that his neck was on fire. Jack said he'd got some green slime on his neck and it was burning - I was thinking the worst, so I told him to go to the reception. When I got there, they'd washed it all off his neck but some was on his shirt, I had to take him home to keep an eye on him.  He is traumatised, but very lucky - I dread to think what would have happened  it had got on his face or in his eye. The mum-of-two thanked the school staff for their quick thinking and asked any witnesses of the incident to contact police. She said: Jack didn't have any exchanges on his way to school - he is a very quiet lad who keeps himself to himself. My son has only just built up the confidence to ride to school with his friends - he can't understand why anyone would do this. He only has a small group of friends, his autism means it takes him longer to connect with people.

title: bride proposes groom lets him
story: NewsBride proposes to groom then lets HIM organise entire wedding - including food, decoration and even her dressEXCLUSIVE: Although hesitant at first, Sarrah Mansoor Nazarali found herself agreeing to sit back and let her groom-to-be organise their big dayShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsBySophie Evans11:19, 1 OCT 2018Updated11:23, 1 OCT 2018NewsSarrah Mansoor Nazarali and Abs Hassanal had a river boat wedding reception "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email When Sarrah Mansoor Nazarali proposed to her boyfriend, she had no idea he would be the one organising their entire wedding day.  But despite her initial hesitation, she found herself agreeing to sit back and let her fianc&eacute take the reigns in the lead-up to the big day.  From the venue to invites, entertainment and and even Sarrah's wedding dress , groom-to-be Abs Hassanali made all the decisions himself.  And fortunately, his hard work paid off - because his bride loved it all. I'm a lot more picky than Sarrah and my nature suited me to take charge of wedding preparations, Abs told . Apparently, men are a lot less hands on with wedding organising, something that definitely needs to change.  But from the venue, to the invitations, decoration, food, cake, entertainment, photographers and even Sarrah's dress and bouquet, I took the lead. Sarrah was hesitant at first to give me the reigns, but I'm just glad I could provide her with the wedding of our dreams. The 27-year-old, from London, continued: Much of the day was a surprise to her and I'm amazed  I could pull it all off. I think our wedding really bucked the trend and showed that men can put together just as an extravagant wedding as women. Sarrah, who wore a stunning pink and gold saree dress for the ceremony, added: Our wedding exchanged the traditional role-play scenario.  I'm the one who pushed to propose and get us engaged while all the organisation for the wedding was led by my husband-to-be. I'm amazed as to how well he managed to pull it all off. Abs had been thrilled when his marketing graduate partner, 28, popped the question in August 2016, two years after they met at a pal's BBQ. But as the far more particular half and determined to give his fianc&eacutee the wedding of her dreams, he suggested that he organise the big day. In a move many brides-to-be would balk at, Sarrah ended up agreeing. She was really hesitant for me to take the reigns at first but I assured her early on, said Abs, a PR consultant who lives in Harrow.  He added that although he did worry his partner wouldn't like particular elements of the wedding, his first decision was a huge hit. I have good knowledge on Sarrah's taste - it comes with the territory of getting married to her, I guess, he told us. In fact, we dfer on all kinds of tastes, including movies, food, gadgets, wallpaper and even clothes! So the pressure was definitely on. I did a very good first job  on the invitations - creating our logo, an invitation video and bespoke invitation cards, so she was overjoyed with the results and trusted me a lot more thereafter. He continued: Of course, with most joint wedding decisions, I took initial input from Sarrah and offered options to choose from. But in terms of deciding the theme and looks, contacting vendors, shortlisting them and ultimately choosing our supplier, it was all me.   Abs went on to choose Sarah's wedding dress, organise a river boat reception and book their venue - the Moat Room at Harrow Registry Office. In an incredible twist of fate, unbeknown to him, his own parents Asgarali and Durraiya Hassanali had wed in the exact same room 37 years earlier. His mum Durraiya had even worn a similar dress to his bride-to-be's gown. [I] had coincidently chosen the exact same room, he said. In the lead-up to the wedding, Abs also ordered a spectacular, nine-tier wedding cake for him and Sarrah, as well as sorting out photographers and decorations. I visited hundreds of wedding outfitters every Saturday and Sunday consistently for four months, he recalled.  I would book consultations in the week and fill up my diary and visit them on the weekend. Most were surprised to see me just walk through the front door. It was often assumed that my other half was parking the car, until elapsed time uncovered otherwise. He added: Asian weddings are a little less traditional white dress for the bride and suit for the groom. It’s all about colour. It's also a tradition in our culture that a gt is given from the groom to the bride to use at the reception - clothes, bouquet, jewellery etc. I just made it my quest to make it all of these! And on the day itself, Sarrah - who had been visiting the UK from Sri Lanka when she first met Abs at the BBQ - was delighted. Abs is far more methodised and particular than I am and it paid idends for our big day, said the bride, whose dress was designed by Jaan London.  He's my le partner and I'm so proud of all that he's done for us. It's the dream start to our long future together. Abs, who shed a tear as Sarrah walked down the aisle, added: We were able to fulfil the wedding of our dreams on a boat on the River Thames. The wedding reception was held on the largest boat on the river, the Dixie Queen, that included the opening of Tower Bridge. The couple were joined by 200 of their family and friends on their big day, including the Mayor of Harrow, Councillor Kareema Marikar. Cllr Marikar knew my we in Sri Lanka before we met due to both their roots, said Abs. She was instrumental in bringing us together. Meanwhile, the groom's parents did a double take as they stepped into the wedding venue and realised they had married there in 1981.  Abs said: It was an absolute honour to be married in the same room of the same building as my parents did 37 years ago. I know it was nostalgia for my parents to be back there all those years later, too. What we didn’t realise, until my parents actually walked in on the wedding day, is that we had coincidently chosen the exact same room. He added: Almost four decades on, and four children and five grandchildren later, their marriage is just as strong today, as it was then. I began married le in the same manner as them and so I hope that my union remains just as endearing for just as long.

title: businessman makes enough money sunday
story: NewsBusinessman makes enough money on a Sunday to close for the rest of the weekChris Lewis, from the Rhondda in Wales has been serving his hugely popular Curlys Dinners over the past 14 years - and Facebook reviews rate the dinners as 4.8 out of 5Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByTyler MearsLaura Forsyth20:28, 30 SEP 2018Updated22:01, 30 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/video/inside-curlys-dinners-13338484,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA savvy businessman has found a way of making enough cash on a Sunday so that he can shut his shop for the rest of the week. Chris Lewis, from the Rhondda in Wales - who's known as Curly because of his corkscrew locks - has been running the hugely popular Curlys Dinners for the past 14 years. Claiming to be the first Sunday dinner delivery service in the Rhondda, the company specialises in takeaway roasts, served in a polystyrene tray. Costing between &pound4.50 for children and &pound6.50 for adults, each portion comes with a choice of meat, vegetables, roast potatoes, stuffing, Yorkshire pudding and a pot of Curly's popular homemade gravy. There's also a choice of homemade desserts, like jam roly-poly and custard or chocolate fudge cake and cream, which start from around &pound1.50. Facebook reviews rate the dinners as 4.8 out of 5, with many reviewers describing the food as beautul, fantastic, good value for money and the best Sunday dinner I've ever tasted.  Despite only opening the shop on a Sunday, preparation work starts as early as Friday for Chris and his team, as they get ready for the weekend ahead. We prep all week - Friday we have our deliveries, Saturday we prepare the food, Sunday we're flat out all day, 43-year-old Chris, a former pub chef, told Wales Online . Starting at an eye-wateringly early 5am, Chris then works constantly until around 4pm on a Sunday. He estimates that his team - which is made up of around eight staff members - prepare, cook and sell between 350 and 380 roast dinners, as well as a number of desserts, every week. This means the company could potentially be making upwards of around &pound28,000 a year JUST by opening on a Sunday. I can manage enough on a Sunday to be closed the rest of the week, Chris said. We sell out mostly every week. We try to keep the prices as low and as reasonable as we can, with plenty of food. I was brought up in the valleys, so I'm used to nice, big plates.  Chris describes his service as a production line and from prepping the veg to pouring the gravy and cooking the meat, everyone on his team has their own inidual jobs. My team is awesome - we're like a well-oiled machine and they've been with me for a long time, Chris said. Everyone has got their own inidual job. Someone is on the phone, someone is on the till, the girls put the veg on the plates and I cook the meat. After leaving school, Chris worked in a fish shop for two years before training to become a chef at his local pub. He spent more than 12 years cooking at the pub, and it was this experience that sparked the idea for his future business. We'd do Sunday dinners at the pub every week and a lot of people would pop in and ask  they could take the dinners away, Chris said. Only around 10-15 people would come in and eat, but loads of people would take dinners away. I could see how popular it was, so when a shop became available I decided to go on my own. Around 14 years ago, Chris took the plunge and opened up his own business in the form of Curlys Dinners. Originally opening as a caf&eacute/diner, the venue had a seating area and a salad/breakfast bar, as well as the takeaway roast dinner service on a Sunday.  We were open for around four years and then I had kids and it all got too busy, Chris said. We closed and I ended up working in a factory for a while. But it wasn't long before Curlys re-opened. When we first re-opened, we were still serving food throughout the week, he said. But after the local bank closed the amount of visitors we had to the caf&eacute dropped. So, we decided to keep it to a Sunday, make it a takeaway service and pour all of our resources into that. We took on more delivery drivers, worked longer hours and it took off from there. Curlys now produces hundreds of roast dinners every month, and the company has established itself as a real player on the Valleys food scene, with queues out the door most weeks. But, there's one month in particular that gets really busy. Christmas is always really busy, Chris said. We're usually fully booked by December 1, and we get orders in as early as September. We've had a hundred orders this year aleady. Christmas dinners at Curlys sell out every year, and costing just &pound12 for dinner and dessert it's not hard to see why. Each festive dinner - which is prepared and picked up on Christmas eve - comes with a choice of meat, potatoes , vegetables, Yorkshire pudding, stuffing, gravy and, of course, pigs in blankets. There's also a vegetarian option and a choice of desserts, including Christmas pudding with brandy sauce. Because our building is so small, we can only do a certain amount of Christmas dinners - but they sell out every year, Chris said. The winter can be quite dficult, especially when it snows.

title: glamour model reveals trade secrets
story: NewsGlamour model and former lap dancer, 38, reveals the secrets of the tradeTanya Cox, from Hull, has been working in the industry for 11 years and says she's now breaking into the 'mature market' of glamour modellingShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsBySophie CorcoranSophie Kitching09:34, 1 OCT 2018Updated10:57, 1 OCT 2018NewsTanya Cox, 38, has revealed the trade secrets of working as a glamour model "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA glamour model has revealed the secrets of the trade from what working on shoots is really like to meeting women who start modelling topless in their 50s. Tanya Cox, 38, from Hull, has been working in the industry since she was 27 but says she often thinks about getting a real job. She was scouted as a glamour model while working as a lap dancer and says her past experience enabled her to be comfortable in front of the camera. Despite loving her job, Tanya says she thought about giving up her career when jobs dried up after she turned 30, reports the Hull Daily Mail.  However, she's now finding success again as she breaks into the 'mature market'. How did you get into modelling and was it something you always wanted to do? I never really thought about doing any modelling work but whilst I was working as a lap dancer, I got approached by an agency and was asked  I would consider doing any modelling work.     I was quite shocked as I thought you had to be tall and skinny to do any kind of modelling but they reassured me that was just the fashion industry and that I was perfect for glamour. How old were you and how long have you been doing it? I came into the industry at 27 and I’m now 38. What was it like at first and what kind of things you were doing? Having already worked as a lap dancer for three years, I was very comfortable with modelling straight away. I think its the taking your clothes off bit that worries most new glamour models but as I had already been doing that for three years, that was the easy part, it was learning to find the light and what angles suited me that took the time the learn. Was you aware of any challenges the industry faced at the beginning? No, when I first came into the industry, everything seemed great, people were much more reliable with higher standards always putting quality first back then. But now its more quantity over quality and trying to get as much as possible shot in the time frame are booked for. Was there ever a point where you regretted getting into modelling? When I first turned 30, my work really quietened off as some companies considered me too old for the young market but I still looked too young to break the mature market. It was a very low point in my le and feeling my career slip away made me so depressed at times that I wished I never started. What has been the best things about it? Are there any moments which stand out where you loved it? I think for me, it helped me to find my own inner strength. I was guilty of never sticking up for myself when I was younger but now I'm the first to say when anyone is out of order, whether it's towards myself, a friend or even a stranger. Also through modelling and dancing, I have now met the best friends that I have ever had. I trust them completely and never doubt anymore that they all love me, as much as I love them. What has been some of the worst things about it? The worst thing about modelling is the high cancellation rates which has been getting worse and worse each year since 2010, but I don't think that is just an industry problem, I think society in general has forgotten its manners because I have noticed that more and more people cancel social meets with friends than ever before too.  Have you ever been judged based on your career? What do you think of that? Not in my personal le, but since my work started to quieten off and I have been trying to get a 'normal job', I do feel like employers are discriminating against me as I don't even seem to be able to get an interview these days, and when I was younger I always found it so easy to get work. When a place I worked at closed down, I had a new job within a week. How successful have you been? I felt pretty successful when I was younger but I do think I would of had a better career had I started when I was younger as it only lasted a few years before my peak ran out. I am now just starting to finally break the mature market, so fingers crossed I can make a success of that, but early days yet. Modelling must have changed since you started - have you seen that and in what way? It certainly has, all the technology keeps changing, I don't know how the photographers keep up. And unfortunately the budgets aren't as big anymore. I really miss the days of make-up artists and clothing departments on all shoots, but these days its only the very biggest companies that provide those now and for most shoots we just get a list of what types clothing to bring with us and have to do our own hair and make-up. Do you think it will change in the future and in what way? We are seeing dferent types of models coming through now We are and I love that we are now celebrating ersity with models now coming in dferent shapes, sizes, styles and ages. I met a new model on set recently who had just started doing topless modelling at 52. Social media has also come to the forefront and many models experience trolling - is that something you've experienced? Yes, I have had a few negative comments but, for every bad comment I get, there is always at least 20 positive comments to counter-act it and the troll then usually ends up getting loads of grief for his/her comment anyway so it always back fires on them.

story: NewsHere's who's paying for Meghan Markle and Prince Harry's upcoming royal tour - and it's not themMeghan Markle and Prince Harry are heading to Australia and New Zealand for their first Royal Tour at the end of OctoberShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer08:48, 1 OCT 2018NewsWho pays for the royal tours? "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Members of the royal family are seemingly always jetting off for tours abroad - take for instance Prince William who recently headed off on a week-long solo tour of Africa. The 16-day visit will coincide with the 2018 Invictus Games, which kick off in Sydney on October 20. But who exactly is footing the bill for this rather exciting trip?  Kensington Palace told  that the costs of royal tours are typically covered by the host government, and that is true for this trip.  A spokesman said: In common with all Realm visits, the costs of the visit will be met by the host governments.   They added that any costs related to the Invictus Games part of the programme will be covered by the Invictus Games Foundation, which Prince Harry is patron of.  During the tour, all eyes will be on the Duchess of Sussex as she gets to grips with becoming one half of a royal tour double act.  The couple will be following in the footsteps of Harry's parents, Prince Charles and Princess Diana, whose first official tour upon entering into married le was also to Australia and New Zealand.  During that trip, Charles and Diana travelled 23,601 miles and spent a total of 41 days overseas.   The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge also visited the same places, being away for 18 days and covering 23,701 miles.  Meghan has revealed she's really looking forward to the upcoming tour. Speaking as part of ITV's new royal documentary Queen of the World, Meghan said she's feeling very excited and hinted that the pair plan on doing more travelling in the near future.

title: mum autistic boy 7 handful
story: NewsMum of autistic boy, 7, with handful of friends makes plea to strangers ahead of his birthdayAlfie's mum Bronya wants to show how loved he is and teach him that it doesn't matter that he is dferentShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByTom BevanKatie Timms12:14, 1 OCT 2018NewsBronya wants as many people as possible to send Alfie a card "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe mother of a seven-year-old autistic boy who struggles to make friends as he cannot speak is appealing for strangers to send him birthday cards. Bronya Thompson, 30, is hoping as many people as possible send her son Alfie a card for his eighth birthday as he loves opening and reading them. The youngster is non-verbal and can only communicate using sign language. He also has a rare chromosome deletion and is one of just eight who suffer from the condition in the world.  Bronya said that due to Alfie's health battles and his struggles to speak he has just a handful of friends as he really struggles to make them and there were only six other children in his class at school. Alfie also has a small family but his mum wants to get him a few more cards for him to open on his birthday on Saturday, October 13, to show how loved he is and teach him that it doesn't matter that he is dferent. She said: Alfie doesn't like toys but loves cards and reading them. It would be amazing to get him a few more he can open on his day to show how loved he really is, and it doesn't matter  you're dferent. We will never know  speech will ever come. He also has hypermobility and struggles to walk and needs a wheelchair, but as you can see from his smile he has a great sense of humour.  Bronya said she also wanted to raise awareness of her son's condition, and that  members of the public see an older child who appears to be having a tantrum, they are probably having a meltdown. I've had a lot of people tut and give comments when Alfie been screaming in town, she added. It's important to remember you cannot always tell that someone is autistic by looking at them. Autism is a disability, not a disease, and does not go away. Everyone who has autism is dferent, some may need more support and some may need less. People with autism find it hard to express themselves, say what they need, or how they feel.

Overnight, the lowest temperature recorded was -1.7C in Eskdalemuir, Scotland, while it was -1.7C at Kielder Castle, Northumberland.  A few places dipped to under 0C, the Met Office said, but conditions should improve amid sunshine today and over the course of the week.  And despite a chilly start to the week, by Wednesday and Thursday temperatures will even be slightly above average.  High pressure will be in charge for much of the rest of the week bringing balmy weather for large swathes of Britain, while staying cloudy most of the time, the Weather Channel says. The best of the warmth will be in the south-east where the mercury could reach 21C by midweek. There is a risk of some sharp showers in the north-west where low pressure and associated cold fronts brush the fringes of Scotland, forecasters say.  But generally for the rest of the UK, there will be some mild days with brightest weather in the north and spells of drizzle possible further south. Winds will be stronger in northern areas of Scotland with a chance of gale force gusts, but it should stay calmer in southern regions and the Midlands. A spokesperson for The Weather Channel said: “It will be mostly dry with a mixture of cloud and bright, or sunny, spells under higher pressure extending eastwards from the Atlantic. “Temperatures will be around normal and above normal in the south and nearing 20C although there could be some rain for the North Sea coasts.”

title: ghostly demonic monk spotted cellar
story: NewsGhostly 'demonic' monk spotted in cellar of slaughterhouse where seven were burnt to death 500 years agoTania Copeman, 41, took two photos as she left The Village in Manfield, Nottinghamshire and was shocked by the resultsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByDavid Keane10:11, 1 OCT 2018Updated14:04, 1 OCT 2018NewsTania and Jared Copeman were on a ghost-hunting tour of the notorious paranormal hotspot "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA couple claim they caught what could be the ghostly 'demonic' face of a monk staring at them in the cellar of a former slaughterhouse - in the same spot he was burned alive 500 years ago. Tania Copeman, 41, was exploring The Village in Mansfield, Nottinghamshire, with Ghost Hunts UK last month when she felt 'compelled' to take two pictures before she left. Tania and her husband Jared, 47, were shocked when one photo showed an 'evil-looking' pale face peering at the out of the gloom, with glowing white eyes - despite no one having been there. Ghost hunter Lee Roberts, who had taken them on the tour that evening, reckons the 'creepy' face could be one of the seven monks who burned to death there in the 1500s.  Tania, who travelled a five-hour round trip from her home in Watton, Norfolk to visit the reportedly haunted location, said: I didn't really expect to capture anything really. But I'd always wanted to go to The Village. I'd heard about that place for a long time and always wanted to go. Jared and I had gone into that section, which we later found out is exactly where they think the priests were burned alive. After we'd done some investigating in that room but hadn't found anything, I just had the inkling to take two more pictures. I even said to Jared when we left 'let me take two more' - and that's when that appeared. But I didn't notice the figure until later when I was looking through my photographs. I saw the two eyes but at the time I didn't realise they were eyes - I thought they were just two white dots. But then I zoomed in on the picture and I saw this face and I was like 'oh my god'.  I shouted Jared and he said straight away that it was a face. After Tania and Jared showed Lee what they had captured, he checked the CCTV to rule out that anyone else had been in that room with them when the photo was taken. When CCTV confirmed the duo were indeed supposed to be alone in the room, they admitted it was 'really creepy'. Tania, a cleaner, said: I was excited to capture something. But then the doubt springs into your mind - could it be a reflection of something? You constantly think, what  it's not something paranormal? But now that everything has been checked. We've confirmed no one else was there, there was nothing there to reflect off - so now it is a wow, what have a caught? The face does look burnt. So it makes me think I might have caught one of the priests that was burnt there. I don't know. It makes you think - what is it? Who is it? It makes me want to go back there and do some more investigating. It's certainly not put me off at all.  Lee says he has tried to recreate the photo and checked the area to ensure there is nothing there that could have made up the shape of a face and is now convinced it is paranormal. The 42-year-old runs Haunted Events UK and also takes groups of ghost hunters on tours of The Village, which was a malthouse and pub after being a slaughterhouse and is a grade-II listed building. Lee said: [Tania and Jared] were both frightened and excited by what they captured. You could tell they had been on ghost hunts before so they were excited. But at the same time they were also wary about going back down there because of the nature of what it looks like. Whether it is a nasty entity or something that it quite nice, because it looks quite evil-looking, it automatically puts that into people's minds. I am quite scientic-minded so the first thing I had to rule out was that it was not something there causing it or pareidolia - and it wasn't. I'm wary of saying things are paranormal but we cannot explain this so therefore this is paranormal. There was nothing there to explain. It looks quite evil and demonic. But that's not to say that it is. That could be just the first form of manestation and that's the way it's been caught in the picture. Even stranger, Tania claims she felt a burning sensation on her face in the same area - before Lee had even told them that monks had been burned alive there.

It is hard to defend United manager Csaba Laszlo now and it would be no surprise  he is given his jotters after this most horric of days.It started when eventual hat-trick hero and former Tangerine Billy Mckay opened the scoring from close range on 11 minutes, knocking in a Josh Mullin cross.The only chink of light in the game came six minutes later as Pavol Safranko got on the end of Fraser Aird&#8217s delivery to guide the ball past Scott Fox in the away net.From there United laboured and County took advantage. Scoring the most simple and avoidable goals &#8211 often carbon copies of each other.The second came on 29 minutes after a Jamie Robson mistake played in Mullin to square for Mckay to knock in.On 41 minutes the same problems United had faced all game down their left-hand side were there for all to see as Sean Kelly inswinging free-kick went all the way through past Matej Rakovan in the home net. A horrible goal to concede with no communication evident and the defence at sixes and sevens.Soon after the restart the Staggies put the game to bed when Mullin and Mckay linked up again with the former this time tapping in from a yard out on 50 minutes.Mullin turned provider, once more, two minutes later laying Mckay&#8217s hat-trick on a plate for him and the Northern Irishman gobbled it up from a matter of inches out.Csaba tried to change things for the Tangerines, but by this point the punters had seen enough and were leaving in their droves and calling for his head in the process, as he brought on Stewart Murdoch and Fraser Fyvie to try to change things on 56 minutes.And three minutes later Murdoch summed up the Terrors afternoon as he was shown a straight red for a stamp on Jamie Lindsay.It capped what was United&#8217s worst performance in years as County saw out the rest of the game with little problem. Is it time up for Csaba?Full details in live blog.&nbsp

title: blether sandy davie returned to dundee united after his stint at southampton
story: Former Dundee United goalkeeper Sandy Davie has featured in this column on quite a number of occasions.We even cleared up the big debate as to why he was in a team photo with Dundee’s championship-winning team of 1961-62.A cutting, dated May 16, 1972, revealed his  for a second stint as a Dundee United player. It read:Sandy Davie is back at Tannadice Park.Last night, team manager Jim McLean completed a transfer deal for the big goalkeeper, an ex-Scotland U/23 cap.It’s three-and-a-half years since Davie  left United for Luton Town for a transfer fee of £8,000.He then joined Southampton two years later.The circle was completed yesterday when Sandy ed for his second spell with United.There was no fee involved.After the transfer, Davie, now 27, said: “I can hardly believe this.“The move came right out of the blue.“I’ve been hoping to get away from Southampton for some time, simply because of the consistency of Eric Martin  gave me little chance of a first-team place.“In my term there, I played just four games for the league side.“But the transfer deadline came and passed, and so did the end of the season.“I thought my chances of an early transfer were slender.“Even at that, I never dreamed that Dundee United would come for me again.”Sandy is married with two young sons.He’ll sell his Southampton house and move north as soon as possible.He’ll be a very valuable member of the Tannadice pool. A point stressed by Jim McLean.Said the boss: “With Donald Mackay away, I need another experienced goalkeeper to join Hamish McAlpine. “Sandy Davie fits the bill.”When Davie left Tannadice, McAlpine was the No 3 keeper, just beginning to challenge Davie and Mackay.McLean also announced that Davie will go on tour with United to Nigeria next week — provided all formalities can be completed in time.Soon after signing, Davie was on the receiving end of ‘jags’ for the trip.It means that 17 Tannadice players will now be making the tour, and it’s an ideal opportunity for Davie to get into the swing of things.On leaving Tannadice for a second time a year later, he emigrated to New Zealand, and played for North Shore United, Mount Wellington and Napier City Rovers.Davie was also capped for New Zealand on 11 occasions.

title: blether this is when east fife previously scored six goals away from home
story: Each week, BwB gives a sample from the Readers’ Queries file in the old Sporting Post.SP Query – On April 20, 1991, ‘Edinburgh East Fe Fan’ asked: Prior to the recent 6-3 win over Alloa, when was the last time East Fe scored six goals away?SP answer – You’ve had to wait over 27 years. East Fe beat Brechin City 6-0 at Glebe Park on January 18, 1964. Scorers were Meechan 2, Dewar 2, McWatt, McLevy .In fact, it’s just under 20 years since the Fers scored six goals at home. On that occasion, they beat East Stirling 6-2 on March 20, 1971 – the year they won promotion to the top ision. Scorers were Hughes 2, Clarke, Finlayson, Honeyman, Quinn.

title: bus drivers from national express hq in birmingham drafted in to help dundee shortage
story: Drivers from the Midlands are being brought to Dundee to try to ease the city’s bus crisis.The Tele understands that five bus drivers from Birmingham arrived in the city this week to drive Xplore Dundee buses.A spokeswoman for the transport company has confirmed that they are being brought in to ease the problems caused by a shortage of drivers.She said: “National Express has centres in Dundee, the West Midlands and Coventry.“It makes sense for us to use bus drivers from these other centres while we have a shortage in Dundee.“We are doing everything we can to ease the disruption to bus services which we are currently facing.”However, the spokeswoman declined to confirm how many drivers had arrived in the city from south of the border.She added: “We maintain our stance that we are working hard, using what measures we can to resolve the immediate issues.”Last week, the Tele reported that dozens of bus cancellations had occurred in Dundee in the last few weeks, causing inconvenience for local commuters.North East councillor Brian Gordon said that his constituency had been particularly badly hit, with 30 services cut over two days last week.He said: “I welcome the fact that Xplore are doing something to deal with this.“However, there are two issues with the English drivers.“One is that they don’t know the routes in Dundee and they’re not going to learn them overnight.“Secondly,  it is just five drivers then that isn’t enough.“Many bus drivers in Dundee are complaining that they are missing out signicantly on holiday days due to them because of the shortage.“Five extra drivers isn’t going to resolve this.”

title: csaba happy to be able to call on quality as dundee united prepare for ross county
story: Boss Csaba Laszlo will be pleased to be able to turn to his bench for support as his Dundee United side host Ross County at Tannadice.Csaba will welcome club captain Fraser Fyvie back to the fold after he missed last Saturday’s 2-0 win over Falkirk due to him not being risked on the articial surface so soon after recovering from a knee injury.He will be joined in the matchday party by winger Billy King as a few other absentees fight back to contention.“With these players coming back it will create more competition and up the quality in training,” Csaba said.“Sam Stanton and Stewart Murdoch are back in training with the team, while Nicky Clark will need another week.“It is important to get these players back to speed.”On Fyvie, Csaba added: “It was a frustration to have a player that can’t play.“We also have to accept that he is a player who has been injured long-term.“It has not just been an easy injury that takes a little time to recover from.“Psychologically, you must also be ready for this kind of match.“As a manager, you have to accept it when a player says ‘This isn’t the best game for me, on the articial pitch’.“For that reason he didn’t play but he will be OK for the Ross County match.”One player Csaba has, sadly, ruled out for the forseeable future is Lewis Toshney.“He has been out for a year so it is not easy for him.“He is fighting to come back.“I am happy that he can train but I don’t think we can talk just now about the first team.”

title: dundee gaffer neil mccann hoping lengthy injury list eases for crunch hamilton clash
story: Dundee boss Neil McCann is hoping his walking wounded recover in time for today’s vital Premiership game against Hamilton kicks off.The Dens gaffer is under pressure to arrest his side’s run of straight defeats – six in the league, seven in all competitions – as the Dark Blues head to Lanarkshire to take on Accies.Martin Canning’s men sit on six points and can move nine clear of their relegation rivals with a second win in two, after a 3-0 thumping of St Mirren last week.Neil will have at least one addition to his options after winger Roarie Deacon declared himself available for action.After a y period out, caused by an injury to his ankle picked up in the last game of last season against Partick which required surgery, it’s likely the former Arsenal man will have to settle for a place on the bench.Last week’s 3-0 defeat to Hibs saw Kharl Madianga, Calvin Miller and Benjamin Kallman all limp off.Finnish striker Kallman’s problem was cramp and won’t keep him out today while Madianga and Miller’s injuries were muscle based and it remains to be seen how long they may be out for.The club are hopeful Josh Meekings will be back fit after a thigh injury picked up against Motherwell four weeks ago.He missed the defeat to Hibs, though, Neil may be tempted to stick with his two loan signings Andy Boyle and Ryan Inniss in any case.At the top end of the field, the Dens boss will be hoping targetman Sofien Moussa has recovered from his knock picked up before the loss to Hibs to give him another option in attack.Meanwhile, Kenny Miller will serve the final game of his two-match suspension today.

title: dundee united sack manager csaba laszlo
story: Dundee United have parted company with manager Csaba Laszlo following yesterday&#8217s 5-1 home thumping by Ross CountyThe club and Csaba have mutually agreed to end his contract effective today, with No 2 Laurie Ellis taking over on an interim basis.Dundee United chairman Mike Martin said: &#8220I would like to thank Csaba for the considerable commitment he showed during his time at Dundee United and for his contribution to improving the underpinning football structure at the club.&#8220We wish him all the best for the future. I can also confirm that Laurie Ellis has taken interim management responsibility for the team.&#8221Ellis will likely be in the dugout for Saturday&#8217s trip to face Ayr United in the Ladbrokes Championship as the Terrors look to appoint a replacement for Csaba.The Hungarian took up the post himself on November 8 last year and leaves the Tangerines sitting fourth in the table and five points behind leaders Ayr.&nbsp

title: exclusive argentina legend claudio caniggia to return to dundee
story: Dundee fans haven’t had much to cheer recently but they will be given a lt with news Claudio Caniggia is set to make a  to the city.The 50-times capped Argentine international – and former strike-partner of Diego Maradona – will be back in Dundee at the Whitehall Theatre on Thursday November 29.Caniggia will be joined on stage by renowned Dundee-supporting journalists Patrick Barclay and Alan Patullo, to discuss his World Cup heroics, that goal against Brazil, his time in Italian football, being offered the chance to  to the national team at 43 years of age, and, of course, his time with the Dark Blues.His arrival at Dens Park 18 years ago, stunned Scottish football and attracted international media attention.Although 33-years-old when he signed for Ivano Bonetti’s Dundee in September 2000, a debut goal at Pittodrie proved there was no doubt that he would still be a star in the Scottish game.Despite being at Dens for less than a season, Caniggia remains idolised by the Dundee supporters and was inducted in to the Club’s Hall of Fame in 2009.The evening will be hosted by broadcaster David Tanner.During his time at Dens, Caniggia wore the No 33 shirt each time he played. Accordingly, tickets for the event are priced at £33.Tickets – including a limited number of VIP Meet &amp Greet briefs – are on sale from 9am tomorrow morning by logging on to thelongestforty.&nbspHelp For Kids are the event charity partner, with a donation being made to the charity for the benefit of local children, and tickets being made available for families who might not have otherwise been able to attend.

title: hamilton boss martin canning wont be shed a tear for under pressure dundee counterpart neil mccann
story: Hamilton boss Martin Canning insists he cannot afford to take any notice of Neil McCann’s plight ahead of Saturday’s clash with bottom side Dundee.Pressure is piling on the Dens Park manager after six straight Ladbrokes Premiership defeats and a Betfred Cup exit to Ayr United.However, Canning noted his side beat St Mirren 3-0 at home on Saturday for their first win in four matches, to give Accies some respite of their own.He said: “You’ve got to go and do your own job and my job on Saturday is to try to get Hamilton Accies three points and  we can do that we’ll be delighted.“That’s just football. We know Dundee will be desperate for the points.“We’ve got to make sure we match that and that gives us the best opportunity.“We’re all going to have spells when things don’t go our way.“I’m pretty sure, same as I do, he’ll believe in his players that they can go and win games and he’ll work hard to try to make that happen.“One result can make you feel a lot better.“I think at times last season, half-a-dozen clubs went through runs of losing four, five, six games and it can happen in this league quite easily.“I thought Dundee were good against St Mirren – very good.“The goalkeeper makes a mistake and they lose the game and from there it snowballs into a poor run of results, so it can happen so easily.“The flip side of it is, you go and win two or three games in a row and it’s a completely dferent complexion.”

title: neil mccann urges his dundee players to give themselves an easier ride
story: Neil McCann has urged his players to “give themselves an easier ride” at Hamilton on Saturday as they search for a first result of the campaign.The Dark Blues have endured a woeful start to the Premiership season, losing their opening six fixtures and scoring just twice.At the start of that run was also a 3-0 home defeat in the Betfred Cup to Ayr United, making it seven defeats on the trot.In none of those matches have Dundee managed to put themselves in front and their gaffer is desperate for the players to at least give themselves a chance of picking up a result.In order to do that, they’ll have to get the better of an Accies side high on confidence after a 3-0 thumping of St Mirren in match that has had a bit of extra spice over the past few years.And despite extra pressure on him to get the result, Neil still has faith in his side.He said: “It’s a huge game, they always have been against Hamilton.“The games against Livingston, Hamilton, Kilmarnock are going to be so important and then Hibs and Hearts.“We are still striving for that first win and we’ll keep trying to give everything to get ourselves that first goal that can at least put ourselves in a position to go and get that first win.“I still think that you could see in the first 45 minutes last Saturday, there is a team there.“I would just love to see them give themselves an easier ride by putting themselves in front.”The Dens gaffer is also hopeful of having some extra bodies back fit after a punishing injury-hit spell.Josh Meekings, Genseric Kusunga, Nathan Ralph and Sofien Moussa all missed the defeat to Hibs with injury while Kenny Miller was suspended.He’ll also miss Saturday’s trip to Hamilton while Kharl Madianga, Calvin Miller and Benjamin Kallman all added to the injury worries last weekend.The good news is winger Roarie Deacon is nearing a  after getting 45 minutes under his belt in a bounce game this week.Neil added: “We’ve not had an easy run of it and it’s been tough to get a settled side out.“We had Glen Kamara and Ryan Inniss back from injury lay-offs on Saturday but it’s been problematic in terms of that.“I have been happy with the squad,  I can get them all fit it would be welcome but we’ve not been able to get that.”

title: something to be proud of majority back dundees new va
story: It has been branded by some as a waste of money and a blot on Dundee’s landscape.But it appears the majority of locals are happy with the city’s new £80 million V&ampA museum.An exclusive online poll by the Evening  has revealed more than 80% of our readers have either already paid a visit to the attraction or plan on doing so soon – about 40% each.Just 18% said they didn’t plan on visiting the V&ampA at all.A total of 444 people responded to our survey featuring a series of questions about people’s early perceptions of the museum of design.Nearly two-thirds of those who took part in the poll said they were happy with the public money that had been used to build and run the attraction.Respondent Stan Riley defended the spending, insisting the benefits “will be reaped many times over” by future generations.Paul McFadyen, from Menzieshill, added: “The money for the project was invested over a decade. I would actually say the museum is good value for money  anything.”Just 7% were “not fussed” about the spend while 32% said they would like to have seen the cash invested elsewhere.Reader Mark Petrie said he felt it would be years before the city knows for certain whether it was worth the money while Alison Donald wrote: “Meantime, what is happening to the people of Dundee using foodbanks?”We asked people to rate the V&ampA from one to 10, based on what they’d seen of the museum so far.A total of 179 people – 40% – gave it full marks, with another 11% giving it nine out of 10 and 10% rating it as eight out of 10.Tele reader Dave Alexander wrote: “I love it, for once we have something to be proud of in our city. Work in progress, I say.”Mike Swan added: “Heck of a lot better than what was there before. Don’t knock it, enjoy it.”Just 49 people, 11% of those who responded, said they’d give it one out of 10, with the other placings spread between 2%-6%.We asked readers to tell us what their favourite part of V&ampA Dundee was. The most popular was the museum’s appearance from the outside, which was top of the list for 170 people – 38% of respondents. 100vw, 620px" /Nearly 30% said the permanent exhibitions, including Charles Rennie Mackintosh’s iconic Oak Room, was their favourite part.A total of 58 people – 13% – voted for the temporary Ocean Liners exhibition while nine folk said the cafe or restaurant was their favourite. Just 79 people said they didn’t like any part.We also asked readers to identy the biggest benefit to Dundee of having the museum. More than 40% said they felt the indirect jobs the museum would bring to the city, through attracting investment from other companies, was the biggest pluspoint.Lisa Lawrence wrote: “It will give confidence to businesses looking to move to the city.“Growth has to start somewhere so why not with this investment in a great city?”A further 22% said they believed V&ampA Dundee had improved the way the city looked, though just 5% felt the biggest benefit would be educating people in design and the arts.A further 6% felt the jobs created by the museum itself was the biggest thing to celebrate.Just 18% of people said they felt the V&ampA would bring no benefits to Dundee.A sceptical Ian McGhee wrote: “In a couple of years one or two of those new hotels will be closed as there are too many of them, and the V&ampA will be used for local kids as a school trip. There won’t be demand for hotels long-term.”

title: we are not manchester city csaba explains why he feels being dundee united boss is the hardest job in scottish football
story: There were some cursory glances around the Press room at the Falkirk Stadium after Dundee United’s 2-0 win on Saturday when boss Csaba Laszlo, almost out of nowhere, asserted the following.“The most dficult job in the Scottish Championship, or Scottish football at the moment, is to be the manager of Dundee United.”He qualied that statement by adding that it is also dficult for his players to pull on the black and tangerine but his remarks did pique the interests of those gathered.It wasn’t so much disagreement or astonishment that filled the room but more a sense of being taken aback by the brutal honesty of a man who has been under such pressure of late.He eased some of the weight on his shoulders with the result at Falkirk under what were strange circumstances – namely going up against predecessor Ray McKinnon in the opposite dugout for a side sitting bottom and pointless.And it was clear that, despite assertions by some that Csaba is daft or clueless, he was very aware of the ramications had he not got the right result.“We showed good team spirit under pressure, they handled it positively,” Csaba commented as he laid out his case to the gathered press.“Now we can close this chapter and look ahead to the next game which will be very dficult.“This is the third season where the fans have been disappointed to be in the second tier and we are talking about a very massive, strong and passionate club that wants to be in Premiership.“If something doesn’t go right immediately you have noise which is OK but we don’t want to hide behind anything.“We have this pressure and we have to accept.“We don’t want to spend one more year in the Championship – it’s not good.“The Dundee United fans don’t want to hear that from the board, the manager or anybody. They want to have the target of promotion and winning the league.“This is pressure, this is normal but you have to understand we have a budget that isn’t any higher than other teams in the main.“You have to bring a team together. We had 19 players leave and 16 players come in for the new season.“We can’t click our fingers and have the team work fantastically.“There are rules at the club about how many or which kind of players we can bring in within our budget.“It is not easy, we are not Manchester City with an owner behind you who can give you £20 million to go and spend.“We have to work with the budget we have to get the best for the club.“The Dundee United board have done a fantastic job. It is not easy to convince players from abroad to come to the Scottish Championship with everything else around.”It was quite a defence – but probably one that was coming after weeks of trying to keep a lid on it following poor results against Alloa and Morton.Yes, he has not had his troubles to seek with injury and scrutiny from all angles but it seems to be just the beginning for Csaba in his most tough of jobs.In the next four weeks they take on title rivals Ross County, Ayr United, Partick Thistle and Inverness. They kick off that run at home to County on Saturday.“I don’t just look at one game being more important than the other because you can’t afford to take any game lightly,” Csaba added. “You have to take every opponent seriously, whether they be at the top, middle or bottom of the league.”
